plugins.name: PixelsConvert
plugins.description:
Get dimensions of layers in different units!

Now you can get dimensions based on the different screen density (in dpi).

Select any one of the six screen densities available-

  • ldpi
  • mdpi
  • hdpi
  • xhdpi
  • xxhdpi
  • xxxhdpi


And get dimensions in five different units as follows -

  • px (pixels)
  • dp or dip (density independent pixels)
  • pt (points)
  • mm (millimeters)
  • in (inches).



Let me hear your feedback/suggestions in comments below or at galwhodesigns@gmail.com

Follow me on Twitter and Linkedin for more updates!


Thanks for stopping by!

plugins.name: Really Flatten Vectors
plugins.description:
Figma plugin that flattens a vector into as few paths as possible. Overlapping paths will be simplified so only the outer shape is defined. The flattening happens in-place.


Usage

  1. Select some layers
  2. Run the plugin by going to Plugins > Really Flatten Vectors or pressing ‚åò/ and searching for Really Flatten Vectors.


Links

  • GitHub
  • Personal Site


Known Issues

  • Flattening inside of a group/frame with auto-layout will not flatten in-place
  • Some invisible layers will be made visible


How does it work?

Generally, Figma simplifies paths when using the built-in flatten ‚åòE on a union layer. This plugin simplifies the setup needed to get a pretty flattened output.

  1. Deeply ungroup/unframe the selection. This keeps positioning simple for some of the later operations.
  2. Outline all strokes. Since this plugin merges everything into one path, strokes cannot be preserved. All strokes and text are outlined.
  3. Use the first valid fill paint data to use as the output fill.
  4. Use Figma's built-in flatten to merge the layers. Figma is pretty intelligent and will place the resulting layer in the correct spot in the layer hierarchy.
  5. Create a union layer that contains the resulting layer from the previous step, and a clone of that same layer. This is because running the built-in flatten on a union with just one layer won't simplify the paths. If there is an exact replica inside the union, then the resulting layer will have simplified paths.
  6. Run the built-in flatten against the union.

accepted.name: steven la
accepted.description: Engineering @figmadesign

plugins.name: skale
plugins.description:
Scale your layers (any layer!) to a specificed width, height or scale value including all properties (strokes, etc). Imagine the scale tool (K) with the power of the properties panel (specify width, height or scale value).


When to use:

Scaling up instances of icons or other layers to a specified width or height (like you would in the properties panel).


Currently Skale only works on instances of components, not on the master component itself. In future releases we'll hopefully see Skale working across all layers.

NEW! Works with all layers, not just component instances!

plugins.name: Desaturate
plugins.description:
Bulk desaturate frames, groups and image fills in one click.


Usage

Select the layers you want to desaturate and run the appropriate menu option - Frames & Groups or Image Fills.


When desaturating image fills, the plugin automatically desaturates all image fills in any children layers in your selected layers.


Shortcuts

After running the plugin once, use the "Run Last Plugin" shortcut (‚å•‚åòP / Alt + Ctrl + P) to run the plugin rapidly.


To undo desaturation, use the undo shortcut (‚åòZ / Ctrl + Z) like usual.


Privacy & Network Access

Desaturate is completely private. It runs locally in your file and does not make any network calls.


Open Source

Desaturate is an open source project and contributions are welcome.

accepted.description: Senior UX Designer @ Epic Games

plugins.name: Tidy Ruler
plugins.description:
Tidy Ruler is a Figma plugin that can wrap your Figma layers in a configurable ruler with accurate pixel measurements.


Getting Started

When you first open the plugin, you are presented with a set of pre-defined parameters that can be used as-is to show you what is possible.


Options

  • Increment: The increment of each ruler mark in pixels.
  • Offset: The hierarchy levels in which your components will be organized.
  • Color: The color of the ruler.
  • Opacity: The opacity of the ruler.


Found a bug or have an idea?

This is a team of one, but if you have any good ideas or constructive feedback, please do not hesitate to share your thoughts by creating a new issue - screen captures are welcomed.


Show your support

If you find this plugin useful, feel free to buy me a üç∫ at my Patreon page. Thanks! üôè


Contribute

  • Run yarn to install dependencies.
  • Run yarn build:watch to start webpack in watch mode.
  • Open Figma > Plugins > Development > New Plugin... and choose manifest.json file from this repo.
  • Create a Pull Request for your branch

plugins.name: Chromatic Figma
plugins.description:
Chromatic Figma lets you use other color spaces than RGB, such as Lab and Lch, to create good-looking and perceptually uniform gradients and color scales. Those are color spaces that, unlike RGB, was created to mirror the visual response of the human eye. That makes them very well suited for interpolating colors, and often produces more natural looking and aesthetically pleasing results.

Usage

Chromatic Figma -> Fix Gradient
This command will take the gradient of the selected shape and add new color stops to create a (in many cases) more aesthetically pleasing one.

Chromatic Figma -> Create Color Scale
This command will create a customizable scale between the fill colors of two selected shapes (or colors chosen using color pickers in the popup)

plugins.name: figma2html
plugins.description:
Export Figma frames to responsive HTML and CSS. A Figma version of ai2html, with additional features. Created by The DataFace.


Learn more about this plugin on GitHub.


Instructions

1. Create your artwork

  • Size frames according to the desired breakpoints. (note: breakpoints are based on width and not height).
  • Name frames using the following format: #[width]px (e.g. #640px).
  • If you're using a Google Font that's built in to Figma, you'll have the option to automatically include the appropriate Google Fonts tag in your exported HTML. Otherwise, you can add your webfonts to your project yourself or include a custom script or link any custom CSS in the Page settings panel.'


2. Run the plugin and configure your settings

  • In the plugin dialog, you can you load your preconfigured settings from a YAML text node named f2h-settings on the current page in your Figma doc, or you can write your current settings to a YAML text node.


3. Click Export and voila, you can save your exported images and HTML file as a zipped folder.


How it Works

  • The plugin grabs all frames named #[width]px on your current page, unframes all children (turns frames into groups to get positions relative to the parent frame), hides all text layers, and exports as a PNG, JPG, or SVG, at a specified scale.
  • All text elements are added via absolutely positioned divs.
  • Text is rendered as <p> (or header) elements. A style is applied based on the most frequently used style within that frame, with inline styles applied to text that differs. This should match what you see in Figma.
  • Text frames with auto widths are rendered with width=auto, while text frames with set widths include that width as inline css.
  • Text is rendered with any visible drop shadows and layer blurs as inline css.
  • The plugin supports rotated text, as well as left/right/center-aligned text.
  • If Include Resizer Script is turned on, the outputted HTML will include JS to show and hide the correct image at the appropriate size, based on the named width of the frame.


Contributing + Feedback

We welcome feedback, bug reports and feature requests in the form of GitHub Issues or PRs. Alternatively, comments can be left on the Figma plugin community page.


Further information on contributing can be found in CONTRIBUTING.md.


Acknowledgements

Figma2html is not possible without ai2html, created by Archie Tse at The New York Times. Figma2html sprung from the same codebase, modified in time to add additional features specific to the Figma API. The plugin was inspired by Thomas Lowry's Figma Plugin DS Svelte library.


The core team from The DataFace features Sam Vickars, Sawyer Click, and Michael Hester.

accepted.name: The DataFace
accepted.description: A digital agency, specializing in data visualization

plugins.tagline: Export Figma frames as images with text elements rendered as HTML

  • Size frames according to the desired breakpoints. (note: breakpoints are based on width and not height).
  • Name frames using the following format: #[width]px (e.g. #640px).
  • If you're using a Google Font that's built in to Figma, you'll have the option to automatically include the appropriate Google Fonts tag in your exported HTML. Otherwise, you can add your webfonts to your project yourself or include a custom script or link any custom CSS in the Page settings panel.'


2. Run the plugin and configure your settings

  • In the plugin dialog, you can you load your preconfigured settings from a YAML text node named f2h-settings on the current page in your Figma doc, or you can write your current settings to a YAML text node.


3. Click Export and voila, you can save your exported images and HTML file as a zipped folder.


How it Works

  • The plugin grabs all frames named #[width]px on your current page, unframes all children (turns frames into groups to get positions relative to the parent frame), hides all text layers, and exports as a PNG, JPG, or SVG, at a specified scale.
  • All text elements are added via absolutely positioned divs.
  • Text is rendered as <p> (or header) elements. A style is applied based on the most frequently used style within that frame, with inline styles applied to text that differs. This should match what you see in Figma.
  • Text frames with auto widths are rendered with width=auto, while text frames with set widths include that width as inline css.
  • Text is rendered with any visible drop shadows and layer blurs as inline css.
  • The plugin supports rotated text, as well as left/right/center-aligned text.
  • If Include Resizer Script is turned on, the outputted HTML will include JS to show and hide the correct image at the appropriate size, based on the named width of the frame.


Contributing + Feedback

We welcome feedback, bug reports and feature requests in the form of GitHub Issues or PRs. Alternatively, comments can be left on the Figma plugin community page.


Further information on contributing can be found in CONTRIBUTING.md.


Acknowledgements

Figma2html is not possible without ai2html, created by Archie Tse at The New York Times. Figma2html sprung from the same codebase, modified in time to add additional features specific to the Figma API. The plugin was inspired by Thomas Lowry's Figma Plugin DS Svelte library.


The core team from The DataFace features Sam Vickars, Sawyer Click, and Michael Hester.

plugins.name: GridMod | Modify GridGen Tables Effortlessly
plugins.description:
How-To Use:
‚Ä¢ Select the parent group of the table and launch the plugin
   ‚Ä£ Plugin is capable of detecting if a valid GridGen table is selected
   ‚Ä£ If selection is changed mid-way through plugin utilization, the last selected table is remembered
‚Ä¢ GridMod is capable of modifying:
   ‚Ä£ The width or height of all columns/rows
   ‚Ä£ The width or height of individual columns/rows
‚Ä¢ Once the necessary inputs are entered, click on "Edit selected grid"
‚Ä¢ GridMod will perform the modification, notify you, and remain open
   ‚Ä£ This allows you to perform multiple edits consecutively without having to reopen GridMod
‚Ä¢ Supports both mouse and keyboard navigations:
   ‚Ä£ "Tab" to go to next input
   ‚Ä£ "Shift + Tab" to go to previous input
   ‚Ä£ "Arrow" keys on textboxes to increase/decrease by 1
   ‚Ä£ "Shift + Arrow" keys on textboxes to increaes/decrease by 10
   ‚Ä£ "Enter" or "Shift + M" on "Edit selected grid" to execute the modification

Current Capabilites:
‚Ä¢ Supports the following modifications of any GridGen-generated tables:
   ‚Ä£ The width or height of all columns/rows
   ‚Ä£ The width or height of individual columns/rows
‚Ä¢ Persistent UI allowing consecutive executions of various modifications
‚Ä¢ Enhanced UI experience with validations and loader

Work-in-Progress:
‚Ä¢ Modification of GridGen-generated table headers

Other feature suggestions are welcome!

plugins.name: UX Stack Guru
plugins.description:
Accelerate your product creation process with the dedicated plugin for Figma and FigJam


Easily search for cards, connectors, shapes, labels, and other components, and drag & drop them onto your canvas, streamlining the flow chart, sitemap, and information architecture creation process.


The plugin works in both Figma and FigJam.

There's also a playground available for FigJam version if you want to try it out link.


What‚Äôs inside:


  • 386 cards for desktop flow charts in 4 colors (Gray, Dark, Blue, and Red)
  • 140 cards for mobile app flow charts in 4 colors (Gray, Dark, Blue, and Red) in paid version only
  • Simplified cards for quick flow charts in 4 colors (Gray, Dark, Blue, and Red)
  • 112 connectors for flow charts, user flows, sitemaps, information architecture, timelines in 4 colors (Gray, Dark, Blue, and Red)
  • 46 shapes for flow charts in 4 colors (Gray, Dark, Blue, and Red)
  • 8 devices for simplified flowcharts in 4 colors (Gray, Dark, Blue, and Red)
  • Hundreds of components such as annotations, labels, numbers & letters, markers, hand-drawn arrows, stickers, note and ticket cards available in many colors (some of them available in paid version only)


Free version of the plugin includes hundreds of vector cards (for desktop), connectors and other elements for creating quick and beautiful flow charts, sitemaps in order to help you with your day-to-day UX tasks.


In addition to the free version of the plugin, the paid version of the product link offers a wealth of additional resources to enhance your UX design process. This includes 140 cards for creating flow charts specifically for mobile applications and responsive websites, a vast array of design elements, the ability to create user flows, site maps, printable sketchbooks, 69 illustrations to incorporate into your designs/products, and templates to help you streamline your UX process, including user story maps, empathy maps, personas, user journey maps, SWOT analysis, card sorting, dots voting, design research, design briefs, lotus diagrams, product canvases, feature planning, feedback grids, and more. You can check out the demo.


If you encounter any difficulties with our plugin, please do not hesitate to reach out to us at uxstackguru@gmail.com for prompt assistance.


Enjoy UX Stack Guru team ü•∏

plugins.name: Table To Figma
plugins.description:
Efficiently import, sync table data into Figma from Notion, Google Sheets, Airtable and local CSV/XLSX/Zip file, and quickly generate tables and components.


Features

------------------------------------------

  1. Sync Notion databases: You can manage and update your table data in Notion and sync it with Figma automatically, without manually importing it.
  2. Sync Google Sheets: If you've created tables in Google Sheets, you can quickly sync the data with Figma using the plugin, so you can use it in your designs.
  3. Sync Airtable Tables: You can manage and update your table data in Airtable and sync it with Figma automatically, without manually importing it.
  4. Import CSV/XLSX/Zip files: You can import table data from anywhere, and the plugin will help you bring it into Figma easily.
  5. Paste Spreadsheet Data: You can copy by using Command/Ctrl + C to select the area you would like to be used as the source data from your spreadsheet.
  6. Generate tables and components: The plugin can quickly generate tables based on your data, and fill it automatically into components of your choice, so you can create multiple components quickly.


Premium Features

------------------------------------------

  1. Quick Rename Layer
  2. Quick Create Frame With Row Data
  3. Apply Cell Values To Layers Quickly
  4. Generate With Custom Layout
  5. Sync Multiple Tables of Google Sheets/Airtable
  6. Update Generated Design
  7. Generated Multi-Tags
  8. Supported Property Columns
  9. Cache Table Data Locally
  10. Import Zip File With Table Data And Images


To learn more about Table To Figma Pro, please visit https://www.thinkbuff.com/table-to-figma


Documentation

------------------------------------------

For plugin documentation, please visit

https://docs.thinkbuff.com/table-to-figma


Data Privacy Protection

------------------------------------------

We prioritize the privacy of your data. Rest assured, this plugin does not save or upload your table data to any external servers. Instead, the data is cached locally on your device for a seamless user experience.


Feedback and Support

------------------------------------------

If you encounter any issues or have suggestions while using the plugin, please feel free to contact us at hello@thinkbuff.com.

We are eager to hear your feedback and continuously improve the plugin for a better user experience.

You can also join our Discord server where we'll be happy to help you.


Thank you once again for choosing our plugin! If you have any

further questions, feel free to reach out at any time. Wishing you success in your design work!

plugins.name: Roughly
plugins.description:
Sketch vector elements to hand-drawn like shapes. Powered by roughjs & inspired by excalidraw.


Easily convert an existing vector element or create a new shapes from scratch -


Convert

  1. Select a vector node.
  2. Choose fill style: hachure | zigzag | cross-hatch | solid
  3. Choose sloppiness intensity: architect | artist | cartoonist
  4. Click Sketch


Create

  1. Select a shape
  2. Choose fill style and color: hachure | zigzag | cross-hatch | solid
  3. Choose sloppiness intensity: architect | artist | cartoonist
  4. Choose stroke width and color: thin | bold | extraBold
  5. Click Sketch

plugins.name: Codia AI Psd2Figma: Import and Export Photoshop PSD
plugins.description:
Fully Editable Figma Layers ‚Äì Now with Bidirectional PSD Support


This tool is designed to enhance efficiency, precision, and security when transitioning between Photoshop and Figma. Whether you‚Äôre importing PSD files or exporting Figma designs, it offers a seamless and fully editable experience across both platforms.


Key Features and Advantages:


1. Bidirectional Conversion ‚Äì PSD ‚áÑ Figma

Easily import your PSD files into Figma or export your Figma designs back to PSD. This two-way compatibility ensures smooth collaboration between teams using different tools and eliminates the need to manually recreate assets.


2. Fully Editable Layers

Every element in your file‚Äîwhether from Photoshop or Figma‚Äîis converted into fully editable layers. Text, shapes, effects, and group structures are preserved with high fidelity, allowing for complete design control in both environments.


3. High Compatibility & Pixel-Perfect Precision

Enjoy near-perfect conversions between Photoshop and Figma. Fonts, blending modes, smart objects, and more are accurately translated, ensuring design consistency and minimal cleanup.


4. Fast and Reliable Performance

Experience rapid file processing with minimal loading times, no matter which direction you‚Äôre converting. This boosts productivity and shortens turnaround time for design iterations.


5. Privacy and Security

Your files are securely handled throughout the entire process. Whether importing or exporting, your design data remains protected and private.


Why Designers Love It:


The Photoshop to Editable Figma Plugin‚Äînow with Figma to PSD export‚Äîrevolutionizes your workflow. Stop wasting time on manual conversions or fixing broken assets. Instead, enjoy fully editable, cross-platform designs with total accuracy and confidence. Ideal for teams collaborating across tools or solo designers switching between platforms, this plugin guarantees smoother handoffs, faster iterations, and more time for creative work.


Call to Action‚òéÔ∏è

For support issues: Slack Twitter Email Codia.AI

  • Unlimited short links.
  • Custom or random alphanumeric short links.

  • Track link views.

All designers

Create your amazing portfolio on Figma and share a short link to anyone.


Agencies, consultants and freelancers

Showcase your work professionally with custom short links. Stop sending huge chunks of urls to your clients and mask your links with a clean and short link.


Product teams

Shorten your links and update them at any time with Linky so your design are always available, even when you make big changes like removing frames or moving them to a different document.


Stop updating your design links in your task management system every time you move things around,

plugins.name: Random Text Generator
plugins.description:
A lean plugin that generates randomized text and numbers for multiple layers as effortlessly as possible.

This plugin was created with productivity in mind, allowing you to create randomized data for prototypes with just a few keystrokes.

How to use it

  1. Run the Random Text Generator plugin
  2. Select the text layers
  3. Write the text you want to use, wrapping the randomized data in as described.
  4. Choose between Replace text (default) or attach to the beginning or end of the selected text layers.
  5. Press return or click the Change text button. Voil√†!

Example uses

  1. Currency amounts ‚Üí $[100-999].[10-99]
  2. Last online ‚Üí Last online [1-9][d;hr;m] ago
  3. Phone numbers ‚Üí +1 (800) [100-999]-[1000-9999]
  4. Status ‚Üí [Online;Offline;Away;Do not disturb]
  5. Adding emails to a list of names using Append after ‚Üí @[gmail;hotmail;yahoo;company].com

What's coming next

  • Find and replace within the selected layers.
  • Allow faster execution of the plugin, using Parameters through Figma Quick Actions menu: ‚åò /

Support or feature requests

Feel free to reach out on Twitter at twitter.com/uxjavi

plugins.name: Frame Exporter
plugins.description:
Export icons with variants.


  1. Customize file names with rules like lowercase, camel, snake, and pascal.
  2. Export as PNG, JPG, SVG, or PDF.
  3. Modify the scale, height, or width.
  4. Include layer modifications in your export - for instance, hide all layers called Background, or add a border radius to all layers with the name Box.
  5. Save, name, and reuse multiple configurations.
  6. Handles variants with multiple properties.
  7. Selection can include frames with and without variants.
  8. Share configurations with a generated code.


If you have questions or suggestions, email naftali@naftalibeder.com or leave an issue at github.com/naftalibeder/figma-frame-exporter.

plugins.name: Time Machine
plugins.description:
Time Machine saves and organizes work that you want to look back on. You'll no longer need to manually copy a version of what you're working on to a new page to reference for later.

Any time you want to save a version, just make a selection and activate Time Machine. It'll send a copy of your selection to a page called "Time Machine" that keeps a chronological timeline of what you've saved.

Your work is organized by date and time, so you can compare side by side as your work evolves.

plugins.name: Spacing Manager
plugins.description:
The Purpose

I think we all know that sometimes designers making different spacings between the elements. In some cases, we have 15px spacing, and in another place, 14px. It's hard always to update all these spacings manually.


With the help of auto layout, we can resolve this problem. Just turn on the auto layout feature with zero spacing between the elements and use "spacers" between.


There are different ways, but I prefer to use the 8-Point Grid System. You can use premade "spacers" from the public library (https://www.figma.com/c/file/809152234949654615/Spacings) and place them between the elements. In that case, you will make sure that the spacings between the components are consistent.


How it works

Add the library https://www.figma.com/c/file/809152234949654615/Spacings or have own symbols that have "$spacing" word in the name;

Use them when needed

If you want to hide them, select a parent frame and run the plugin. It will look for all spacers that were used on the frame and will set zero opacity

If you want to show spacers back, just rerun the plugin. If the first spacer on the row will have zero opacity, it will set 100% for all spacers found on the selected frame.


Pro tip

You can use smart spacing prediction feature! Here is how it works https://twitter.com/faridsabitov/status/1281697269948067845


Pro tip

You can set "cmd"+"option"+"H" hotkey via system preferences in Mac to toggle spacers visibility quickly. You can read more about setting the hotkeys in Figma here: https://hustle.bizongo.in/custom-shortcuts-for-figma-8c93f3bc9ca2

plugins.name: Sticky Notes Kit
plugins.description:
Previously called Project Notes.


A plugin to help you create documentation for your designs. With this plugin you can attach notes to layers.


New Updates:

  • Brand new UI
  • Turn ON/OFF the signature and timestamp
  • Ability to customize the position of sticky notes
  • Customize Time format of the signature - choose either DDMMYYYY or MMDDYYYY
  • Notes are created with Auto Layout
  • Removed search functionality
